Immediately, Makoto stepped into her role as president. She placed a hand on the council member’s shoulder, “It’s okay, just calm down and tell me what’s wrong.”

“I lost all of the school festival’s paperwork, the approved class event plans, the club events plans, the classes’ special request forms, the festival floorplans, the budgets, all of it – I’m so sorry!” He said. Makoto’s went wide and she felt the life force slip from her body for a moment as she stood there stunned, hoping that she simply misheard him.

“I was a little behind on double-checking the paperwork, so I put it all in a few folders to take with me, and I was going over the documents earlier today any chance I got, during class, between class, while walking around the school, in the bathroom, in the locker room, I’ve been everywhere already today” He said, amazing Makoto by how much he could say with so few breathes. “And, I don’t know when or where I lost them. I thought I still had them with me, but I was wrong. I’m so sorry…”

If you were to ask most students at Shujin how they thought their president would take this news, they would recommend that the messenger run for the hills because it would not end well. Those students would be wrong. Instead, Makoto cast him a soft gaze, took in his tear-stained face, and sighed, giving him a pat on the back. “It’s okay,” she said, trying to offer him a small, reassuring smile. She saw no point in giving him a hard time about it, especially not when he was clearly already giving himself one. “I’ll find them, don’t worry.” Despite saying that, she couldn’t help but wonder whose idea it was not to back up the documents in the event something like this happened that got them into this mess in the first place.

“You mean it?”

“Yeah, I’ll find them in no time,” Makoto said, giving a thumb up and an earnest smile. Or so she hoped, at least. The festival was only a few weeks away, and they couldn’t afford to spend the time to remake the budgets and plans. They were pushing the deadline as it was, and if they didn’t meet it there wouldn’t be a festival. Makoto refused to let that happen. Finding those documents were now her top priority.

But what exactly was she going to do? The school day was only about halfway over, but she could start searching now. After all, the longer they’re missing the more likely something could happen to them. It wasn’t like she couldn’t afford to miss a few classes, and her absence would be excused since it was official student council business. It did not take long for Makoto to make her decision. “Starting with the bathroom would probably be best,” she thought aloud. It was the lesser of two evils, and if she were caught, it was far more defensible than being in the boys’ locker room. She could simply try to play it off as a case of her being momentarily unobservant when she headed to the girls’ bathroom. “Now that I’ve settled that, I just have to go to the…” Makoto fell silent as the gears turned in her head and her eyebrows furrowed some. And she soon came to a realization. “I forgot to ask which bathroom he used…”

Makoto quickly slid open the Student Council Room’s door, hoping that her fellow Council member did not get too far away yet. But, when she cast her gaze up and down the hallway, he was nowhere to be seen. A small sigh escaped her lips. This made things a bit more difficult. Instead of only having to check one bathroom, now she needed to check them all. It was a rookie mistake – she should have known better. Internally, she kicked herself some. Absent-mindedly, her thoughts drifted to how her sister Sae would have handled the situation.

Makoto knew her sister would not have been as sympathetic, if at all, to the Council member as she had been. There were many words to describe Sae, serious and strict being the most opportune. But sympathetic did not seem to be one of them in recent years. Her sister always desired for and strove toward success. She did not take mistakes lightly. She also never seemed to make them. She would have remembered to ask the Council member which bathroom he used before dismissing him…

Shaking her head to clear the thoughts away, Makoto knew she did not have time to waste getting caught up on something like that. No, she was on a mission! And she knew just where she would start. Makoto walked swiftly down the hallway and turned left, walking past classrooms until her feet finally led her to the entryway of the bathrooms. On her left was the girls’ bathroom, and on her right the boys’. Neither had a door. Instead, the entryways each wrapped around white-tiled walls so that no one could see in from outside. It assured that whoever was inside received at least some measure of privacy, which was something Makoto ordinarily approved of and supported. However, today, as she stood there listening closely, trying to identify if anyone was inside, she could not help but to consider the feature to be a nuisance.

Makoto stood outside the bathrooms listening closely for any noise coming from within while she also kept a watchful eye down the hallway, making sure there was no one there to catch her in what she was about to do. She didn’t see anyone. Nor did she hear anyone inside the bathroom either. It seemed like the perfect chance to investigate, yet she found herself hesitating, her feet not yet willing to let her break the taboo. She breathed a deep breath and forced herself forward, bracing herself for whatever was about to come. Makoto was well-aware of the stereotype that boys’ bathrooms were often filthy, but she hoped it was wrong. As she rounded the porcelain tiled wall, she was greeted with the sight of a shiny white room with three black-walled stalls and three urinals up against the left wall. On the right side were three sinks on a black counter-top connected to a mirror that reached the ceiling and spanned the length of the counter-top. She released a relieved breath, “I knew they couldn’t be as messy as they say.”

Upon first inspection, Makoto did not see anything lying around in the bathroom, so her next course of action was to check the stalls. Much like the rest of the place, each stall she checked seemed to be clean. In fact, they were too clean. Everything was pristine, without a spot of mess to be seen. “Maybe the janitor came through here recently?” She said, standing in the middle of the room, looking at the sinks. There wasn’t even so much as a drop of water on the counter. “If they did, I imagine that they would turn in anything they found…” Makoto stood there, her mind at work, for a moment. Honestly, she would admit that she wished the documents would have been in the first place she checked. Then, she could have the relief of knowing where they were and been able to return to class, but it seemed her journey had to continue.

And it would be in your best interest for this to be done without us releasing those pictures. After all, you’re a bright young woman with a promising future ahead of you, so long as we keep these pictures under wraps.” Mr. Words said. “I believe we’re being more than fair in giving you a chance to clear your debt another way, don’t you agree?”

Makoto stood quietly. Honestly, she had to admit it was better for her that they came to her with this offer rather than just releasing the pictures and being done with the whole matter. But what if these tasks were just going to keep spiraling until she’s put in a worse situation than before? She didn’t have much time to dwell on the thought before Mr. Words spoke up again, “We don’t have all day, Miss Makoto. Are you going to continue completing our tasks or would you rather we release the pictures?”

Makoto hesitated for a moment more before finding her voice. “How many more of these ‘tasks’ involve me losing articles of clothing? Because… because if your plan is to strip me completely to repay my ‘debt’…” Her blush deepened at just imagining the prospect.

“I’m going to stop you right there, before you say something you might regret, Miss Makoto,” Mr. Words said, cutting in. “If you start imagining all the what-ifs and things that could happen, you’ll just work yourself up. I can guarantee that not all the tasks we give you will involve you losing clothing. Who knows, maybe in some tasks we might even give you some clothing. But, needless to say, some of our tasks will require you to shed some clothes. Of course, it is perfectly understandable, expected really, that a respectable, upstanding young woman such as yourself is concerned about her dignity. And, although I can’t say whether or not or plans for you will involve getting you naked, I can say this: so what? Hypothetically, Miss Makoto, let’s say you do find yourself naked in public and you get caught. What would happen?”

“I… I would make up an excuse! I’d come up with something to explain why I’m naked, like that I was robbed or-“

“And what if the police got involved, then what would happen?”

“If they believed me, they would likely get me something to coverup with and have me give an official report of what happened before taking me home.”

“And if they didn’t believe you? What’s the worst that would happen then?”

“They…” Makoto’s voice caught in her throat. “They might charge a fine… or potentially detain me… They would call up my sister, and she would come pick me up.”

“And your sister might even get that kept off the record,” Mr. Words chimed in. “But even if she didn’t, how badly would that affect your future?”

“It wouldn’t change much of anything,” Makoto said, her voice merely a whisper.

“On the other hand, how much would those pictures being released affect your future?” Mr. Words’ voice said, patiently continuing to guide her answers like one would a small child.

“The school would have to perform disciplinary action…” Makoto answered quietly. “I would be suspended or potentially even expelled. Then, that would go on my record and might keep me from getting accepted to any prestigious schools… which would limit what careers I could go into… and…”

“And would tarnish your bright future.” Mr. Words finished for her. “We certainly don’t want that, now do we?”

“No…” Makoto didn’t know what else to say. They had her between a rock and a hard place.

“I’m glad to hear it, Miss Makoto. Besides, what’s a little embarrassment now compared to happy life later on?” Mr. Words said. “Now that we’ve decided that, let’s continue. Head to the underground mall in Shibuya and ditch that bra. We’ll even be so kind as to let you decide which shop you want to ditch it in. But do be quick about it, we don’t have all day. I’ll leave you to it-”

“Wait, I have one more question!” Makoto said, voice coming out rushed. She had an idea that could at least make this ‘task’ less embarrassing for her. “Can I take my bra off somewhere else first, like the bathroom or something and just drop it off in one of the shops afterwards?”

The answer came quick, “No,” Mr. Words said with a small chuckle. “That’s half the challenge after all. It might be better for you to think of this as a game, have some fun with it, and it’ll be over before you know it.” With that, the line went dead.

After all, it was her own recklessness that got her where she was now, and that was probably what stung most about this whole situation.

Maybe it was because they actually might try to take those next? Thinking about it, Makoto felt a shiver go down her spine and dread building up in her stomach, she certainly hoped that wasn’t what was coming next. Honestly, she wasn’t too far from the mall, but the time it would take to get there would be both too long and not long enough for her.

As she walked, she found her eyes drifting to watch her chest. Her eyes stared so intently and harsh that they might have burned a hole in her dress if she were able. She searched for any hint of her bra through her dress, seeing if any spot of the dress was transparent enough to see through, and she wasn’t finding any. “Maybe I was wrong.” She said to herself. “Maybe it won’t be noticeable at all.” She could only hope.

All she had to do was walk through the entryway, go down a flight of stairs, and she would arrive at her destination… Then the real challenge would begin… Forcing herself forward, Makoto was greeted by the station’s refreshingly chilly air conditioning as she entered the building and approached the stairs. Her hand touched the top of the railing, and she hesitated, staring down the stairwell. A handful of people were ascending, not a single one appeared to be paying her any mind, yet she suddenly found herself concerned with the length of her dress.

Her dress wasn’t short by any means, especially not in comparison to what she has seen other girls wear. But, without her leggings, she began feeling a little self-conscious. As people started moving around her to descend the stairs, Makoto steeled herself. It was silly of her to be so nervous over something so trivial. Though, that thought didn’t stop her from holding the bottom of her dress down with her free hand as she descended. She took no time celebrate her victory over the stairs, making her way toward the Underground Mall the moment her feet touched down.

It was more crowded than she expected, full of families, kids running around, and people her own age just hanging out. She expected the place to be nearly vacant, considering the time. Admittedly, though, she didn’t know much about the mall. She had only been there a handful of times, and each of those times Ann had been dragging her along, telling her it was the perfect place to relax. Makoto didn’t feel too relaxed, quite the opposite. She was a bundle of nerves as she circled the mall, looking for the best place to complete her task, while also trying to keep an eye out for anyone tailing her without looking too suspicious. She was sure she was failing.

She knew from shopping with Ann that the mall had a couple clothing stores, Lovely Melody and the ever-crowded Problem Child. Normally, clothing stores would be the best place to ditch clothes, or at least one would assume. It didn’t certainly didn’t seem that way to Makoto. Lovely Melody seemed to have a steady number of people entering and exiting it. Problem Child was worse. No matter the time, it seemed Problem Child always had an enormous crowd in its rather small store. Whenever you were in it, you were always shoulder-to-shoulder with someone else. And due to the hole-in-the-wall nature of the stores in the Underground Mall and the need to maximize space, neither of the clothing stores appeared to provide changing rooms for their patrons. Makoto cupped her chin in thought. If the obvious choices were out, where could she get her task over with?

Makoto walked around the mall, scanning every business within it with a critical eye. The worst locations seemed to be the Shoe Repair store, the Sundry store (though, she would admit, it did have cute book covers), the Souvenir store and the Umbrella shop. The latter two hardly had enough space in their stalls for their product let alone customers. The jewelry stores weren’t any better, but for the opposite reasons. The mall apparently housed three different jewelry stores, each one spacious and open. Honestly, she commended their ability to maximize their spaces while still leaving plenty of room for customers to browse. However, that was part of the problem. In each of those stores, there would be nowhere for her to hide her bra after she removed it – if she even could without being seen. Likely due to the rather expensive cost of their product and quite possibly her age, the employees in each of the jewelry stores watched her like hawks. Similarly, the employee in Body Chop, a cosmetics store, was stuck to her like clue after she entered it, but she chocked that one up to the employee having nothing else to do than anything else, because they had been very friendly.

Makoto did eventually manage to find a few promising locations. Across from Body Chop stood a shoe store called Beauty Feet. Inside, the walls were covered with displays of shoes and shoeboxes. There were even aisles with shelves that nearly reached up to her eyes. She would be able to have at least an illusion of privacy if she did it there. A few stalls away from Beauty Feet was a purse store that for a reason Makoto couldn’t identify was named Funny Face. Similarly, it was not crowded, and its large, circular displays provided cover for her. Plus, she would be easily able to hide her bra in one of the various purses. Aside from those, the only other promising store was Babel Records, a music and DVD store. It had the benefit of an inattentive cashier, who seemed more interested in his phone than doing his job, and a large shelf of CDs that would provide cover the wandering gazes of people looking through the establishment’s wall of windows. She was deep in thought, weighing the pros and cons of each option, when a ringing noise snapped her out of it. Tentatively, Makoto pulled up the phone she had been given and answered it. “Hello?”

“Do I need to remind you, Miss Makoto, that we don’t have all day for you to finish this?”

"Excuse me? May I address one final item?" Haru Okumura asked, biting back her nervousness as she rose to her feet and all eyes turned towards her.

The meeting had gone better than expected so far. There was a notable number of disapproving expressions and dirty looks among the board members and shareholders, but most of the business people at least seemed impartial or even cautiously supportive of her being there. And of course even her most ardent critics had not had the courage to challenge the acting President Takakura when he insisted on allowing her to sit in and contribute to the meeting. Most of her suggestions and thoughts had all been regarding new branches of the company and quality in their food and products, and while using higher quality ingredients and offering actual benefits and decent schedules to their workers was going to be expensive the board members were at present most concerned with rehabilitating the company image after the more heinous of her father's practices had come to light. Therefore, a passionate plea for cleaning up the company from the heiress was not at all unwelcome, although Haru wasn't naive enough to think this enthusiasm would remain so high when the cost analysis for the reforms came in. But that was a worry for the future. For now, she was only top happy to ride the wave of general enthusiasm for her proposals as much as possible to propose something truly controversial.

"I think it would be prudent...to run an internal audit on company gains and losses over the past year." Haru said.

"....Not that I object to the idea, Miss Okumura. But we routinely check the books several times a year." One of the executives chimed in. "Why do another one so soon to the end of the quarter?"

Haru breathed in. This was it. "I believe, in light of recent events, we should do a focused audit around the dates of all mental shutdown cases in the last year. Appraise how our company profited, and especially which branches benefited most. And which people."

There was a long silence.

"Miss Okumura...I understand that you'd be as eager to catch the Phantom Thieves as anyone after what they did to your father, but surely this is a matter best left to the police?" Another boardmember popped up.

Haru frowned. Of course she knew that the Phantom Thieves had nothing to do with her father's murder, since she was in fact one of them. "I am not fully convinced this was because of the Phantom Thieves. As detective Akechi has stated, this does not fit with the pattern of their past work. And of course the mental shutdowns were happening well before the first incident of the Phantom Thieves."

"Clearly that was their business prior to this stealing hearts routine." One of her critics said.

"Again, I don't find that convincing. If the two phenomena were coming from the same group, why create the phantom thieves at all? Let the incidents and deaths be written off as stress related or fluke accidents. Why deliberately draw attention to your ability to affects people's minds as the Thieves do when you were profiting perfectly well in secret?"

The board members exchanged looks and whispers a moment. "An...interesting theory, Ma'am, but surely it remains a matter for the police?"

"You misunderstand. I don't want to find the Phantom Thieves or the mental shutdown instigators. I want to ensure we are no longer doing business with them or anyone tied to them." Haru said, laying her hands on the table.

Takakura leaned forward in his seat. "You think someone in the company besides your father had contacts with them?"

"That's my concern, yes." Haru nodded. "I loved my father, but the knowledge that he would go so far as to drive his competitors insane or even kill them makes me ashamed! And the thought that anyone else in this company conspired with him, and perhaps was in any way associated with his death...that is unforgivable! I fear we cannot possibly move forward or make a fresh start as a company until we have identified any and all areas of corruption leftover from my father's actions!"

"Surely you aren't suggesting any significant profit made in those timeframed is a clear indicator of guilt? What if that is merely an example of shrewd business sense and the timing is a coincidence? Or perhaps your father merely wanted to grow that area of the company and his managers profited without knowledge of his methods?" Another executive objected.

"I am merely suggesting this as a place to begin. Obviously further investigation would be needed before any kind of action would take place on the company's part." Haru said.

Really, all she wanted were a list of names. She doubted anyone in bed with her father would be capable of existing without a Palace or a shadow in Mementos. Rattle off all the names on the list and see which ones the App reacts to. The Phantom Thieves would take care of the rest.

"Miss Okumura...do you believe anyone at this table is a part of this...corruption, as you put it?" Another executive asked.

"....I don't want to believe that. But after what I learned about my father, my faith has been shaken. I no longer know who I can trust personally or professionally. I believe the public currently faces the same doubts. Not to mention our shareholders. We want to restore trust, and that begins by knowing who can be trusted. I realize that is a lot to ask, especially for those who have been here the longest. I also hope you can see the necessity and can have faith that the truth will come out and loyal, dedicated members of our company have nothing to fear from any probe we conduct." Haru offered.

As expected, the mood around the table had darkened considerably. Takakura at last cleared his throat. "If we were to approve this audit, I presume we should begin with the Wild Duck Burger case?"

Haru paused. "Wild Duck Burger?"

"Yes...umm...earlier this year there was an incident in which a wild duck burger employee suffered a breakdown and came to work without any clothes on. The incident caused a scandal, forced Wild Duck to close several locations, and effectively eliminated them as a competitor due to their damaged reputation."

"Oh...yes. I...heard about that." Haru blushed. "I had not made the connection."

The meeting went on. No firm agreement on an audit was reached, but the idea was better received than expected. A recess was called for lunch. President Takakura moved to pull Haru aside as the other executives shuffled out.

"That was a...bold suggestion, Miss Okumura." Takakura said.

"Thank you. I think it went well."

"Indeed. But are you certain this is wise? Poking a hornet's nest of killers could put your life in danger."

"Thank you for your concern. But I don't believe I will be a target. I think my father's death means whoever is responsible for these mental incidents has cut ties with the company. Anyone associated with them has to fend for themselves now." Haru said.

That was a lie, of course. She firmly believed their mysterious rivals in the heart stealing business were still connected to the company. But unlike her father, Haru had a Persona instead of a shadow. Unlike a shadow, there was no way to murder her by attacking her other self.

With that in mind, Haru took her leave and made her way to a subway platform to get some lunch before the meeting began again. Meanwhile, in Mementos, a figure covered in black watched her indistinct approach. This was a thin space, much like the safe havens dotted throughout the Palaces. Here the lines between the real world and Mementos were thin enough for the two to visually oscillate back and forth. Akechi had learned that in such places his unique Persona abilities could pass over and touch the minds of people in the real world. Of course, it was not lethal the way killing a Persona was. But he had a special talent for corrupting shadows and personas, driving them somewhat mad. Which was good. He had no desire to kill Haru Okumura if possible. But a message should be sent. A warning. And a bit of humiliation. A repeat of the Wild Duck incident should suffice quite nicely. And his contacts within Big Bang Burger would reward him handsomely for delivering that message promptly.

info.description:
Welcome to the Persona 5 ENF interactive. If you have participated in some of the other excellent ENF interactives, including several from the Persona series, you will already understand how this works and can move right to the next section. Otherwise, please read on.

Oh yes, and just to state the obvious for the sake of posterity, THESE CHAPTERS WILL INCLUDE SPOILERS FOR THE VIDEO GAME. If you haven't played the game (and you should, it is as good if not better than the previous games in the series) please do so before reading further. It will give you a better understanding of the setting and the characters. Plus it supports the hard work of the people at Atlus, without whom we would have no female characters to write about and humiliate. So do that, and come back here to share your ideas! Thanks!

PERSONA: This interactive is set in a video game setting known as Shin Megami Tensei: Persona, or just the Persona series. Persona 5 is the fifth major title in this series (okay, technically it is the 6th if you factor in Persona 2's two games, and I'm not even bothering to count all the special editions and spinoff titles....let's just keep it simple!). The games all take place in the same universe (for the sake of simplicity, we won't be thinking too hard about Persona 1 and especially Persona 2 since it basically ended and rebooted the universe). The series generally deals with concepts pulled from Jungian psychology- to wit that the human mind is made up of various archetypes and that our myths tap into psychological traits shared by all humanity since the start of civilization. In the Persona verse, these archetypes manifest as Personas (masks people wear to deal with the traumas of day to day life, similar to the concept of the Ego) and Shadows (desires and thoughts that the mind rejects and suppresses in the subconscious). Both Personas and Shadows are broken into varying Arcanas loosely based on the Tarot Deck. The human collective unconscious (also called the Sea of the Human Soul) is a world unto itself, and the games typically explore the idea that some unknown manifestation of humanity's corrupted desires is working to influence the physical world in some unhelpful way. There are endless sub-realities in the Sea of Souls in which Shadows gather and Personas can manifest. Some of the these realities co-exist or touch upon the real world (such as a 'hidden hour' that most people aren't aware of, or a portal that certain people can open by touching a TV screen). Personas cannot generally be manifested in the real world (again, ignoring some of the implications from Persona 1 and 2), nor do shadows usually exist in the real world. But under the right circumstances (usually very bad, cataclysmic, fighting the final boss kind of circumstances) these mental realities can fully intrude on the physical world. The player usually is tasked with stopping such events. One rare example of a completely beneficial Unconscious reality is a place called the Velvet Room. It exists between dream and reality, mind and matter, and only opens to a talented guest, often one with a rare Wild Card talent for holding many personas inside their mind at once. The master of this world is called Philemon, a god-like entity that nurtures human potential and guides Persona Users. Since the second game, Philemon has manifested solely as a butterfly, leaving the affairs of the Velvet Room to Igor his creation and various subordinates that serve him known collectively as the Sisters of Power (even though there is at least one male among their "sisters").

PERSONA 5: Every Persona game has their own themes and motifs. Persona 3 was all about living life and accepting the inevitability of death. Persona 4 was about seeking out the truth, even when it might be painful, and rejecting the excuses, lies and fantasies people tell themselves to avoid seeing the reality around them. Persona 5 is in large part about justice and captivity, and the bleary nature between the two, especially when society itself seeks to shackle and punish the innocent while protecting and empowering the corrupt and criminal to the point where the only possible form of justice left in the world requires stepping outside the bounds of the law. In more practical terms, P5 revolves around a group of Persona users called the Phantom Thieves, who discover a mental reality called a Palace, which congeals over the physical world based on the distorted desires of a single corrupt individual. These same users also learn that taking the Treasure of that reality will cause that corrupt person to regret and confess their crimes and abuses to the world. The game jumps deep into the gentleman thief/heist genre, with most of the Palaces being popular settings for such fiction (bank vaults, casinos, art museums, ancient tombs, etc.)

Please feel free to invent more corrupt villains and Palaces. If possible, think about the general themes of the game and of course the ENF genre when doing so. There's plenty of ideas to draw from. Wild West holdup, 1930s speakeasy, exclusive gentleman's club, hidden pirate cove, anything really. Generally have fun, but stories that stay somehow within those themes are greatly preferred (don't go bonkers and throw into some kind of sci-fi space station from a completely unrelated genre, that would just be...ummm...you know what, we're moving on!).

ENF: Simply put, ENF is a type of adult erotic story involving Embarrassed Nude Females. That's the (no pun intended) stripped down version of the story- girl loses in clothes in a way or place that makes her embarrassed at the situation. Broadly speaking, this genre appeals to and can crossover with Voyeurism, Exhibitionism, BDSM, humiliation, submission/dominance, bondage, and so on. What the genre does not often consist of is things like rape, sexual violence, vore, gorn, and similar stories. Now, some of this may feel ambiguous. I am aware that there are many grey areas in this context, and that my personal ENF stories and tastes might be more extreme than others in this community. Please email me if you are concerned that your story might cross a line (and I will try to warn you if I have misgivings about your content as well). As a general rule, public nudity (obviously), sexual arousal, being forced to strip for any reason short of being physically attacked, being spanked or whipped, any example of masturbation or self-gratification, getting caught on camera/posing naked, groping (unwanted or otherwise), and consenting sex of all kinds is never a problem. More than that is going to depend on context and generally just how you as a writer portray the situation and the characters. As a very specific in-game example, if what you want to happen in this story reminds the audience of what Kamoshida puts Shiho through in the opening portions of P5, then you have 100% crossed the line and need to scale it back.

Anyway, after that lengthy diatribe, let's get down to the ladies.

Ann Takamaki: http://megamitensei.wikia.com/wiki/Ann_Takamaki A blonde haired, blue eyed model of a mixed American, Japanese descent. Ann is by nature a care-free soul who saves her vindictive streaks for those who try to threaten or hurt her or those she cares about. She is perhaps a bit less shy than some of her female comrades due to her modeling career, able to for instance laugh off her friends lewd expressions at seeing her in a bikini. Still, she can be quite sensitive and embarrassed if she sports too much skin or is placed in too suggestive a manner (the catsuit she manifests in the Metaverse being too skintight for her liking). Underneath the surface Makoto harbors frustration towards those who see her as either useless or just a pawn for their own schemes and longs to prove herself and walk her own path. That desire has proven useful in combat but also gotten headstrong Makoto into situations she could not easily extricate herself from.

A eccentric girl with waste length orange hair, thick 'nerdy' glasses, and a somewhat petite but very cute body. Futaba is on one hand a flippant, even crass girl steeped in the language and understanding of games and the internet. On the other hand, she has suffered from years of being a shy and guilt ridden shut in. The thieves have taken it upon themselves to 'train' her out of her crippling phobia of people and the public. Fair to say that being naked in public, while a humiliating situation for any of the girls, will be absolutely crippling for Futuba if she cannot find a way to cope with it. Hiding her face has worked in the past, as has the main male PC escorting her as her 'key item'. Course, the latter example would result in him seeing her naked, but one works with whatever they can find in these situations. Also worth noting, based on comments she makes in Mementos, that she finds the female Phantom Thieves costumes rather 'kinky'. Make of that what you will.

Haru Okumura http://megamitensei.wikia.com/wiki/Haru_Okumura Born into riches and luxury but expected by her father to be meek and obedient, Haru has only recently discovered the joy of rebellion and rejecting what others expect of her. Not truly naive but not nearly savvy enough to differentiate true allies from those who want to use her for her influence and money, Haru has come to rely almost completely on the Phantom Thieves when it comes to who she can trust. She regards the others as mentors, especially Morgana. Much like Futaba, the thieves are the foil through which Haru is learning to be assertive and confident in herself...but that is a very long road. Certain comments also suggest that Haru uses the fights with the Shadows as a method to stress relief and harbors a bit of a sadistic streak when they beg for their lives. What other secret thrills she might harbor in defiance of what is expected of her, or how she feels about other examples of people begging (including herself) can be left to the imagination and the writer.
